snippet: The plan to sell the first long-term bonds in four years is a symbolic turnaround for Greece, even if legions of jobless Greeks are not cheering.
abstract: Greece returns to capital markets with plans to begin selling long-term bonds; deal represents major milestone for the country, which was effectively shut out of the markets in 2010; bond sale reflects increased optimism that Greece and other wobbly euro zone countries have turned the corner.

byline.contributor: Niki Kitsantonis contributed reporting from Athens and Melissa Eddy from Berlin.

lead_paragraph: The plan to sell the first long-term bonds in four years is a symbolic turnaround for Greece, even if legions of jobless Greeks are not cheering.

headline.main: Greece Dives Back Into the Bond Market
headline.print_headline: A Milestone as Greece Dives Back Into Bonds
